doc.repnme: "Backstop" lending for capital market development in Argentina
doc.abstracts: This Note discusses the Argentine Capital Market Development loan, approved by the World Bank's executive directors in March 1994. The Bank provides a US$500 million loan to the Argentine Republic, which in turn has a subsidiary loan agreement with the newly created Backstop Fund. Banks that meet established standards of credit to participate will be required to demonstrate that their pool of term loans meeting certain qualifying criteria grows by at least as much as the issuance of backstopped bonds. This project addressed systemic risk and other aspects of market development. The project has become known in the World Bank as the "Backstop Facility." But that name does not do justice to the scope of the project because it does not reflect its important development features. This Note describes the project design and how it differs from traditional World Bank lending. It also explains why this structure was chosen and how it will allow banks to provide longer-term loans to qualifying borrowers. In general, the rollover facility concept underlying the Backstop Fund will apply to those countries whose markets have begun to develop, but are constrained by longer-term liquidity concerns, the absence of broadly used financial instruments, and the lack of well-established institutions.
